exercise_suggestions.exercise_suggestion: As your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal reduce your mealtime insulin by approx 25% and reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60- 90mins before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
As your exercise is before your meal reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60- 90mins before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
3. No additional carbohydrate should be needed for this duration and intensity of exercise
4. Check blood glucose before you start exercise (aim for a starting blood glucose between 7-10mmol/l) and at the end of exercise.

As your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal reduce your mealtime insulin by approx 50% and reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60- 90mins before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
As your exercise is before your meal reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60- 90mins before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
3. No additional carbohydrate should be needed for this duration and intensity of exercise
4. Check blood glucose before you start exercise (aim for a starting blood glucose between 7-10mmol/l) and at the end of exercise.

As your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal reduce your mealtime insulin by approx 75% and reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60- 90mins before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
As your exercise is before your meal reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60- 90mins before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
3. No additional carbohydrate should be needed for this duration and intensity of exercise
4. Check blood glucose before you start exercise (aim for a starting blood glucose between 7-10mmol/l) and at the end of exercise.
1. Your blood glucose will likely rise with this extremely intense exercise therefore take your usual meal time and basal insulin if your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal
2. You will unlikely need any carbohydrate to prevent hypoglyaemia during exercise but always carry some with you
3. Check blood glucose before you start exercise (aim for a starting blood glucose between 5-7mmol/l) and at the end of exercise.

As your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal reduce your mealtime insulin by approx 50% and reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60- 90mins before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
As your exercise is before your meal reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60- 90mins before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
3. Consume additional carbohydrates as needed based on your blood glucose monitoring (approx 10-15g/hr). Remember the more insulin you have on board the more carbohydrate you will need.
4. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 7-10mmol/l), during exercise and at the end of exercise.

As your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal reduce your mealtime insulin by approx 75% and reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60- 90mins before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
As your exercise is before your meal reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60- 90mins before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
3. Consume additional carbohydrates as needed based on your blood glucose monitoring (approx 10-15g/hr). Remember the more insulin you have on board the more carbohydrate you will need.
4. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 7-10mmol/l), during exercise and at the end of exercise.
This exercise intensity is not possible for this duration. Change exercise intensity to moderate
This exercise intensity is not possible for this duration. Change exercise intensity to moderate

1. If your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal reduce your mealtime insulin by approx 50% and reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60-90mins before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
2. Or if your exercise is before breakfast or >3 hrs after your meal reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60-90mins before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
3. You will unlikely need any carbohydrate to prevent hypoglyaemia for this duration and intensity of exercise but carry some with you
4. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 7-10mmol/l) and at the end of exercise

exercise_suggestions.warning: * Only receive this advice if the input team sport / gym (resistance + cardio)
exercise_suggestions.exercise_suggestion: As you are doing both resistance (e.g weight-lifting) and aerobic (e.g. jogging), do resistance exercise first to reduce the risk of hypoglycaemia during and after exercise .

exercise_suggestions.warning: * Only receive this advice if the input team sport / gym (resistance + cardio)
exercise_suggestions.exercise_suggestion: As your exercise is team sports remember a match or competition will likely cause your blood sugars to rise due to nerves / adrenaline, therefore you will need less insulin dose reductions and less carbohydrate than you might need during training
1. Your blood sugar will likely rise with this extremely intense exercise therefore take your usual meal time insulin and basal insulin if your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal
2. You will unlikely need any carbohydrate to prevent hypoglyaemia during exercise but carry some with you
3. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 5-7mmol/l) and at the end of exercise

exercise_suggestions.warning: * Only receive this advice if the input team sport / gym (resistance + cardio)
exercise_suggestions.exercise_suggestion: As you are doing both resistance (e.g weight-lifting) and aerobic (e.g. jogging), do resistance exercise first to reduce the risk of hypoglycaemia during and after exercise .

exercise_suggestions.warning: * Only receive this advice if the input team sport / gym (resistance + cardio)
exercise_suggestions.exercise_suggestion: As your exercise is team sports remember a match or competition will likely cause your blood sugars to rise due to nerves / adrenaline, therefore you will need less insulin dose reductions and less carbohydrate than you might need during training

1. If your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal reduce your mealtime insulin by approx 50% and reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60-90mins before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
2. Or if your exercise is before breakfast or >3 hrs after your meal reduce your basal insulin by approx 65% about 60-90mins before the start of exercise until the exercise stops.
3. Consume additional carbohydrates as needed based on your blood sugar monitoring (approx 10-15g/hr). Remember the more insulin you have on board the more carbohydrate you will need.
4. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 7-10mmol/l), during exercise and at the end of exercise.

exercise_suggestions.warning: * Only receive this advice if the input team sport / gym (resistance + cardio)
exercise_suggestions.exercise_suggestion: As you are doing both resistance (e.g weight-lifting) and aerobic (e.g. jogging), do resistance exercise first to reduce the risk of hypoglycaemia during and after exercise .

exercise_suggestions.warning: * Only receive this advice if the input team sport / gym (resistance + cardio)
exercise_suggestions.exercise_suggestion: As your exercise is team sports remember a match or competition will likely cause your blood sugars to rise due to nerves / adrenaline, therefore you will need less insulin dose reductions and less carbohydrate than you might need during training
This exercise intensity is not possible for this duration. Change exercise intensity to moderate
This exercise intensity is not possible for this duration. Change exercise intensity to moderate
Anaerobic exercise is done at moderate to high intensity. Change to at least 4-6 on the intensity scale
1. As your blood sugar is likely to rise with anaerobic exercise no reduction in mealtime insulin or basal insulin is advised.
2. You may need to increase your basal rate during to avoid hyperglycaemia - try increasing by 10% 30mins before to 60mins after.
3. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 5-7mmol/l) and at the end of exercise
Anaerobic exercise is done at moderate to high intensity. Change to at least 4-6 on the intensity scale
1. As your blood sugar may rise or remain stable with anaerobic exercise, therefore no reduction in mealtime insulin or basal insulin is advised.
2. Carry some carbohydrate with you as you may need it to prevent hypoglycaemia for longer duration anaerobic sessions
3. If your blood sugar tends to rise you may need to increase your basal rate during exercise - try increasing by 10% 30mins before to 60mins after.
4. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 5-7mmol/l) and at the end of exercise
